description.text:
A modified upper holder with hook to attach on top of shelves. Based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1809185

Only upper hook made. Rest can be downloaded from link above.
A magnifying glass for your lego detectives, both as a single mesh and as two objects to allow separate printing of the lens.

Printed at standard settings (0.2mm layers, 2 shells, 10% infill). Leave in original orientation for faster printing. When printing the lens frame separately and flat there is a high probability that it will print some of the frame circumference as a chord. If this happens it should be trimmed to keep as much of the circumference intact as possible.  
To fit the separate lens into the frame put it in place and press firmly. If it doesn't immediately pop in rest in on a hard surface and use a rigid tool (such as the flat of a knife blade) to gently force it into place. The fit was easier with a vertically printed frame, but also worked with frames printed flat.
USB on the right side

This is my version of a classic Tron light cycle. It was designed and built in TinkerCad. I separated out the main parts. The windows, wheels and main chassis cover are removable as you can see in the images. I did this to allow you to print the parts more easily. I have also supplied both static as well as working versions of the wheels so if you want to make one that can roll, or just one for display I've got you covered. I've also given you simple half versions of the full cycle as well as the wheels.

The model is just under 8 inches in length. It was not sized to hold a figure or anything like that, I built this based on multiple images with my primary focus on the actual movie footage. The bikes change from scene to scene though so I had to take some artistic license with this. It doesn't exactly match any one version but is a compilation of all the versions shown in the movie.

I have not printed this yet, but will upload photos when I do.

Thanks and happy printing programs!

description.text:
Siege Engines for desktop. Semi-Functional/Moving parts on the Trebuchet and Ballista. I hope to add an improved rail to the Ballista so that it is usable with rubber bands.

These Prints are optimized for a 0.4mm Nozzle. This really comes into effect when putting the pieces together.

Assembly

Trebuchet
Use the Handle or a 2.5mm Dowel to secure the arm to the base.
Use a string to hang the bucket on the end of the Trebuchet for holding weights, such as rocks or steel ball bearings or lead sinkers. Let people know what works best.
Feel free to glue the supports(stand) into the base but I wouldn't suggest gluing anything else as most parts need to be able to move freely.

Ballista
There is a block on the front Slot of the Head mount. This is here to make it easier to print, carefully cut of the front block and the Ballista Head will slide nicely onto the Ballista Arm. Feel free to glue this part.
The Arm is mounted to the Stand with a 2.5mm Dowel. Try using the StandShort for the Ballista to get a better angle.
Put tiny rubber bands(Like the ones for braces) over the pegs on the back, tie a string to them and wrap it through the side slots on the head of the ballista.

Cannon
Glue the 2 halves of the Cannon together. The side with a peg goes on top.
You can fit it in the SiegeBase with StandShort but it also has its own CannonStand.

My modifications to the SEEJ starter Set from 2013- I liked the pennies rather than the cannonballs.
Overall, changes have been made to pretty much every element.

  • The struts are thinner and the axis has been moved.
  • I made it a little skinnier overall, just to save plastic.-- I've noticed that this is a flaw and I'm going to make a wide-body version soon
  • The atlas is deeper and includes some sights for aim.
  • The rear bar includes a trigger system- The pins are pretty tiny, though, a piece of wire serves better.
  • The front bar now has prongs for mounting to a height bar that will let you, when mounted to the base, aim up or down by 5 degree increments.
  • The base is new, includes a hole for centering on a drawn or printed compass, and a line cutout to view your angle. The struts mount on the new rear hinge.
  • Added peg holes on each side to mount penny caddies for ammo (Also gives you some mass)
  • Guides on the struts AND the new throwing arm to slot your rubber bands into, to make cleaner twists.
  • Arm is longer, can be printed without supports.
  • The key now has a cutout, so that you can add a rubber band without cutting or knotting. Rubber bands simply fit over the entire machine and slot in.

Suggestions for further modifications are appreciated!
More pictures to come.

comments.author: trastero86

description.text:
After numerous failed designs, I've finally created some corner clips that keep a glass bed from shifting without the clip sitting on top of the glass surface itself in a Monoprice 11614 printer (Flashforge Creator Dual knockoff).

This design relies on you inserting an M3 nut into each of the tightening wheels you print.

I printed mine out of PETg simply because I like the flexibility and high temperatures it can withstand, but ABS would work, and PLA would probably be OK too, as long as you dont print with a very hot bed temp.

I printed mine solid as well just for the extra strength...you could probably print it with less plastic, but as I havent' TRIED that, I cannot confirm.

I am currently using 2 of these in opposing corners and they hold the glass perfectly still...no need for 4.

Also, you may want to print out a spacer to re-zero the Z axis sensor...like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1332275

NOTE - in this case, I'm using an 1/8" piece of borosilicate glass (Pyrex). If you're using thicker or thinner (neither are recommended) then you will have to adjust the Z spacer as well as perhaps the thickness of the upper lip of the clip. The gap between the upper lip and the bottom may also have to be modified if your bed isn't approx 8mm thick from the top of the bed to the bottom of the circuit board.

title: Adjustable Raspberry Pi & Camera mounting solution for Prusa i3

description.text:
I needed a good solution to mount my raspberry pi and camera to my Prusa i3.  
I adapted an existing pi mount that I found was not strong enough and kept breaking after printing, and also added an adjustable camera arm that clips onto the frame, based on an adjustable fan duct.  
Openscad files are provided if you need to tweak anything.

You will require 2 * M3 screws 12mm long or longer. Print all of the stl files or adjust and re-export in openscad. Note: The mounting clip (clip.scad) will probably need support enabled and some cleanup after printing unless your bridging is super awesome. Assemble the camera arm before putting in the camera to avoid damaging the ribbon cable. You may need to slightly cleanup the pins on the camera case so they fit through the circuit board.

Este es mi prototipo de P3STEELcon toda una serie de mejoras que crean (bajo mi punto de vista) una de las mejores Prusas modificadas del mercado.
-La estructura está pensada para ser fabricada en acero de 3mm de grosor como todas las P3STEEL, lo que le da una robustez realmente buena. He de añadir que aunque ha sido ampliamente modificada esta estructura, la base es de HTA3D
-A diferencia de la gran mayoría de impresoras 3d NO UTILIZA CORREAS DE GOMA, si no que utiliza husillos T8x8 en todos los ejes lo que le añade más precisión, menor número de guías de acero, mas robustez y no requiere de calibraciones ni tensado al cabo de cierto tiempo
-Esta totalmente preparada para soportar una cama de 200x200 o una de 200x300 lo cual hace que sea muy versátil
-El extrusor está totalmente diseñado para ser de plástico lo que le da ligereza al eje X, pero no se basa en un sistema de engranajes (los cuales se acabarían desgastando).El diseño de dicho extrusor es de HTA3D
-Como el eje Z es movido por husillos no es necesario utilizar guías de acero, solo un anclaje tanto al inicio como al final de dicho husillo a la propia estructura principal de acero.
-Solo utiliza 3 tipos de rodamientos comunes, por lo que es muy facil de encontrarlos (y bastante barato también)

Esto es tan solo un prototipo, el cual estoy en proceso de de montaje y prueba. En cuanto tenga nuevas noticias lo iré actualizando

remixed_from.author: markinthebox
remixed_from.title: Kobayashi Fidget Cube - Fat Hinge - Flat

description.text:
This is a 2-color version of the Kobayashi Fidget Cube (laid out flat to make it printable) intended for printing with a dual extrusion setup. The two components of the model - the cubes themselves and the hinges that connect them - have been split into separate models. Combine them in your slicer, assign each model to a specific extruder, and watch the magic happen!

It should be obvious, but I'll say it anyway: you can not print these parts separately and then assemble the fidget cube - the cubes and hinges must be combined and printed at the same time.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I'm still awaiting the multi-material upgrade for my printer so I've not yet been able to print this split model. Pictures will be posted when available.

UPDATE 02/2017: I'm still awaiting the multi-material upgrade, but user asr93 has already printed this model and allowed me to use his photo in this listing - thanks!

I have printed the original (single extrusion, flat) fidget cube successfully on my Taz with no supports.

title: Simple tiltable snap-in frame for G4-type LED lamps

description.text: I needed some good lighting to illuminate the print bed of my DIY RepRap. I tried to keep it as simple as possible, but still flexible enough to direct the light beam into whatever direction I needed to look at in detail... So out came this little tiltable and rotatable snap-in frame, on which I mount the easily available and inexpensive round G4 type 12V SMD LED lamps. These are basically small circular PCBs with 5050 type SMD leds and are sold in 6-led, 9-led and 12-led versions. On eBay you can find them for around 1$ each. The frame consists of two printed parts: the LED holder and the base. These two parts are joined by a conical hinge, so that the angle of the lamp can be adjusted as needed. The conical hinge holds by friction, but screw holes are also provided in case a firmer grip is needed. The led holder is designed to allow as much air circulation as possible around the led carrier, to allow for proper cooling. The frame has a central screw hole so that it can be attached to any flat surface. If a washer is used and the screw is not tightened too strongly, the lamp can also be rotated around the screw, providing full angular coverage. A hole in one corner of the frame can be used for feeding the cables through. The led carrier is simply pushed into the led holder - it should snap in with a click. Depending on the type of led carrier you get, you might have to unsolder the lateral G4 mount and solder the wires directly to the solder pads located in the center. Note that these led carriers usually also contain a rectifier, so that you don't have to worry about polarity. The SCAD file that is provided is parametrized, so that the design can easily be modified to individual needs, or also to fit the even larger 15 or 24-led carriers. The provided "ready-to-use" STL files are for the 6-led, 9-led and 12-led versions. (Note that I have no 9-led carrier, so I could not test the 9-led version in practice yet.) Even though I first just thought of using these lamps inside my RepRap, they have turned out to be useful in many other places as well... Update 2014-02-03: I just have received a new batch of 6-led modules and, to my dismay, these only have a diameter of 22mm, so the don't sit firmly in the 23mm frame. Thus, I have now uploaded and additional STL file for the 22mm version.

comments.text: Search on aliexpress of ebay for "g4 led 5050 round 12V" and you will find a lot of these LED lamps.  The all have extruding 2 lead wires (either radial or central at right angle) which you must unsolder befor you can use the lamp in this design.

comments.text: Nice design, simple, elegant, good mechanical match.
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text: I haven't seen yet G4 LED carriers with active current regulation circuitry.  Mine just have a rectifier and some current limiting resistors on the back, and these fit nicely inside the frame.  Since you have the OpenScad source, you could also modify the source to allow for more space behind the LED carrier.  The simplest way to do this is to increase the value of "wall".
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text:
Hi again,
today, I received the flatter, non-regulated 30mm LED arrays. Unfortunately, the components on their back still stand out proud, they won't fit into the basic holder. Maybe 0.3 mm missing there.
I tried hard to find out how to increase the distance between the bottom plate and the PCB resting holder. No success so far - it's surely just me being blind for the obvious.
Would you mind, if your time allows, to add some howto-lines into your scad-sources that teach people like me how to change that? I had no problems to widen the gap for the wires leaving the pcs sideways, also opening the bottom of the holder was no problem. Just that d....edicated height parameter... It's probably that multivariant use of the variable name 'wall'. Sorry..
comments.author: enif

comments.text: As I already wrote above, the easiest is to modify the value of "wall", especially if it's only 1mm or less. But make sure that you change the value at the right place, best in the call to module ledholder() at the end of the scad file.  If you change it in the default value at the definition of module ledholder(), it might get overwritten by the value passed when calling...
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text: OK, so I increased 'wall' from 2.25 to 3.25 in the ledholder call. (Had done that before, but now I understand better what I am doing there, and why I did not like the result before.) - Yes, the height of the space for the backside population of the pcb increases. Success.
comments.author: enif

comments.text: Yes, I agree that the increasing the wall was just a stop gap measure, the problem being that I assumed that a back space equal to the wall thickness would be sufficient.  I have now changed the OpenScad source by adding a new parameter "ledB" which defines the space needed at the back of the led carrier.  I have uploaded in the file named ledframe2.scad.
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text: Excellent! Thanks! And have a nice christmas!
comments.author: enif

comments.text: Thanks - you too! :)
comments.author: Chattermark

comments.text: Thanks for the prompt reply. I tried that - no avail.
comments.author: enif

comments.text: One of my first prints, It was great. I scaled up the 24mm by 108% this achieved my size being 26mm! I experimented with the settings using 2mm layer height and it was really good. Me and my teacher will print again to 0.01 layer height to see how good the printer can go! Thank you for the great design, I will upload some photos and share! Thanks !
comments.author: trevorboultwood

comments.text: Nice build!!! Thanks a lot!
comments.author: didierh

comments.text: Love it! Especially that it's parametric. Thank you very much, kind sir!

comments.author: tech3d1

description.text:
I designed this for a class, see http://www.appropedia.org/Adjustable_Bike_Mirror for printing and assembly instructions. A brief summary is below

Mount the two clamps onto the bike handlebars using two zip ties. Using the adhesive that came on the mirror ( I used a blind spot mirror for a car that you can pick up for $1 at Walmart such as this one ), or using superglue, attach the mirror to the flat part of the base. Put the balls from the rod and base into the appropriate sockets of the mount and find a position with the rod and base that suit your liking, then remove the balls and apply some super glue to them. Reinsert the balls into the sockets and allow to dry. (I find that gluing the balls in the sockets may or may not be necessary, depending on the tolerances of the printer.
Pay attention to the orientation of how the parts are printed in the photos below. For the top clamp, make sure to use supports and print it so that the joint is on on the side, this maximizes the strength of the socket. For the rod make sure NOT to use supports and print it ball side UP (socket faces down).
Rod: 50% infill, 0.2mm layer height, print with the ball up, no supports. If your printer has difficulties with printing this for some reason, use a small raft.
Base: 15% infill, 0.2mm layer height
Top Clamp: 50% infill, 0.2mm layer height. Print with supports and the joint on the side as shown in photos below.
Bottom Clamp: 25% infill, 0.2mm layer height.

I uploaded the source files so you can modify it to your liking.
Bear low poly

author: imabiggles

title: Car Dock for Sony Xperia Z3

description.text:
I was getting tired of those wobbly cell phone holders, so I made this dock. I included the STEP files, if you want to modify this for your phone.
It is really specific for the Sony Xperia Z3, and with my phone cover on as well, so really specific... (maybe works with other Xperia, not sure). It takes advantage of the magnetic charging port. So you drop the phone in, and it starts charging right away, because it lands on a magnetic charging wire. With Tasker I made it so that when the phone is connected to my car's bluetooth system, and it is plugged in, the car app starts (shown is Car Dashdroid, awesome app by the way!)
If you dont want to charge, you press the "eject button" on the top, which just lift the phone up above the magnetic charger. Also makes it a bit easier to get the phone out.
The big step on the back makes the phone sit lower, in front of the dash, which does not block the view at all.
If you want the charging to work, you will need to buy a magnetic charging cable like this one: https://www.amazon.ca/Magnetic-Performance-Charging-indicator-Compact/dp/B015WIV7O2/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1480384154&sr=8-7&keywords=xperia+z3+magnetic+charger

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

To print this, it needs pretty massive supports, in 2 places. 1 thin support for the top cross bar, and 1 big support for the back step. If you download the file "Car Dock-V2.stl", you will have all the supports needed. The file with "no support block" in the name, well... does not have the big support block, in case you want to generate your own support. But it still has the top cross bar support, because that one is really good, it works awesome, I would not replace it by automated support there.
The 3 small pieces, I printed with 100% infill because they are so small.

I ran out of black filament, so I used some ugly blue one I had and painted it mate black.
To stick it on the dash, I used 3 strips of padded double sided tape, and it sticks really good.

description.text:
Soap Dish

I had a problem with the soap in the shower falling to the floor because the soap dish was installed wrong. So I build a quick little tray that would keep this from happening. My wife saw the tray and said she needed one for the bathroom sink. Well I could not put my simple one in a place people might see it (it was rather simple) so I wasted a day and built a more elaborate tray.

The one pictured was printed in low-res/low density mode to see if it would work. My printer had a couple of minor hiccups while printing, but it will function for now. The bonus is that now anyone with a similar sync can have a set of soap dishes.

The design is to hang over the outside edge of the sink to prevent the dish from visiting the drain.

This does require using supports to print since the overhang is lower than the dish. If you want you could reduce the back leg and print without supports.

I have included the designer file for Autodesk 123.

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

300

Infill:

60% or higher

Notes:

Density Level

The one pictured was printed with very low density and it is pretty light and my break easily. I recommend a higher infill setting to make it more solid.

description.text:
Here's my totally untested design for entry in Cathal Garvey's Mousetrap challenge.
(Challenge: http://blog.makerbot.com/2010/03/01/cathal-garveys-mousetrap-design-challenge/ )
(Cathal: http://www.thingiverse.com/cathalgarvey )
Thankfully I don't have the vermin problem Cathal does. The downside is that I have neither tame nor wild mice to test this design on. The idea is to cut out most of the lid from a peanut butter jar and insert this printed lid. Hopefully it will allow the mouse inside to feast on the delicious delicious peanut butter but not let them out. (Who would want to leave a room lined with peanut butter anyhow?) For design notes about this thing, check out my blog at www.makerblock.com. FYI, I think I'm the first one to include a jar of peanut butter as a "part"!

Eat most of a jar of peanut butter
Cut out most of the lid to the peanut butter jar
Print the Peanut Butter Jar Mousetrap Insert
Insert the Peanut Butter Jar Mousetrap Insert with the pokey bits going inside the jar.
Set somewhere a mouse can get to with something on top so it doesn't roll away.
Wait.
Peanut butter covered mice!

description.text:
A pill bottle for a keychain that will hold 3 - 4 8mm or so diameter pills. Designed for a co-worker that is allergic to bees and has to carry some pills around.  
Updated 5/28/14 - I added an stl for a gasket I made out of flexible filament.

This was one of my first tries with Openscad. You will need the "Thread Library.scad" from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 Print out the three pieces (cylinder body, cap and hook). Glue the hook into the cap with acetone / abs glue (dissolved abs and acetone). Screw the cap onto the pill bottle then unscrew and screw it back on a few times to loosen it. If needed you can add a dab of silicone or cooking oil on the threads. Possible improvements: Use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095 to put on a knurled finish on the cap. I saw this library after I had made mine and put groves in my way. I printed at 100% fill .25mm layers on a Makerbot TOM w/MK7 *update 5/28/14 - I added an stl for a gasket I made out of flexible filament. It worked well.

comments.text: I have seen something like that before (not connecting all the way). It may be related to retraction distance (when it reverses extruded on corners). The infill should be solid. It may be related to the 100% infill bug if using hexagon infill. Change to line or rectangles if on hexagon on the Fill settings. Let me know how it goes. My friend that I made one for out of abs put it through the washing machine and he pills survived. I made mine out of PLA and the lid fit much smoother than abs because of the lack of shrinking problems that abs has.

title: Nervous Kinematic Bracelet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I ran across Nervous Systems [email protected] app, based on their Kinematics post. This is a bracelet I made for my wife based on that system. Can't believe how well it turned out! You can download and print this thing, or go to the above link and make your own.

After I designed the bracelet and downloaded the stl, the first print failed: Turns out the stl was pretty messy (many holes and separate shells). I ran it through Netfabb Cloud and the resultant stl (uploaded here) printed great on my Replicator (1).
I got ahold of Nervous Systems: They said they're still working on the app, and hope to have those issues resolved in the future.
  • Glass build platform with hairspray, HBP off.
  • 2 shells
  • 0% infill
  • Light silver pla, extruded @ 220 deg.
  • Printed in 1 hour, 18 minutes.

comments.author: stewardj

comments.text: On the first one I printed, before I ran it through netfabb, the clasp area is what failed as well:  It didn't fill in the volume of the clasp with the little knob, making it very fragile.  And the clasp on the other side fused with the kinetic bits.  I contacted nervous system explaining the problem:  They said they were aware the 'smooth' version had issues when making clean mesh, but they were working on it.  They said the sharp version should produce better mesh in the meantime.  Too bad netfabb didn't work for you :(

This is a replacement fork bushing for the Honda XR50. It may likely fit other models as well, like the Z50, or CT70, maybe. Of course there's nothing like brand new replacement parts, but, if you don't have them handy, then printing out your own might be a good alternative.

I made these bushings out of ABS, and although I was skeptical of how it would react with grease, I am pleased to say we have been using this machine for several months without any problems.
I expected the bushings to begin de-laminating as a result of exposure to grease, but so far so good.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 layer height (standard)

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with ABS

Checking for a good sliding fit...

Be sure to check for fitment often, by briefly sliding the greased tube into the bushing while in the leg. If it is too tight, then you will need to either hand ream with the 7/8" drill, or shave the OD a little with a coarse file.

Check for fitment often, so you don't make it too loose. special sizing requirements...

It may be necessary to perform a mild "hand reaming" using a 7/8" drill bit. Be careful not to take off too much.

Be sure to check for fitment after a few turns by briefly sliding the tube into the bushing while in the leg.

Hand reaming using a 7/8 drill bit. Cleaning up the outside...

It may also be necessary to lightly clean-up the outside diameter of one or both of the bushings with a coarse bastard file.

Be sure to add plenty of grease upon reassembly.

Cleaning up the OD with a coarse file makes for a precise fit.

author: PIROZZI

description.text: i just added a hole in his tail s you can feed a key ring or some string through.
Just a cute Harley Quinn picture (not used with permission) embossed.

An edited ReconstructMe print of me! Instead of the full head, it's just a bas relief - no nose- or chin-droop overhang to have to deal with.
Special thanks to Tony Buser for  the NetFabb cutting lesson, and to Brian Stamile for the tweaks to my Thing-O-Matic voltages.

1 - Get a Kinect. Get ReconstructMe. Play.
2 - Get NetFabb. (If you have a Mac, wait until the third week of March when they say it'll be fixed.) Or get the PC version and cut the scan down though the middle so you have a nice flat base.
3 - Check all your Thing-O-Matic's stepper voltages.
4 - This one was printed with 4 shells and a 15% infill.

Now that Makerbot has been bought out by Stratasys, who's next?

  • The proverbial pie for consumers of 3D printing is growing larger by the day. Stratasys wants more pie.

    • What are your thoughts on the situation? Makezine article of the lawsuit against the folks of the UP! Printer:

  • http://makezine.com/2013/11/27/stratasys-sues-afinia-ramifications-for-the-desktop-3d-printing-industry/

    • PDF of claim filed by Stratasys:

  • http://forums.reprap.org/file.php?1,file=21811,filename=10114908932.pdf,download=1

    • Credit for this idea goes to Jeremy Zimmer I won't keep using Thingiverse and encourage yo to do the same

  • There are plenty of other services now: https://www.youmagine.com/ https://cubehero.com/ http://www.bld3r.com/ http://www.fabster.com/ ...

comments.text: This is pathetic, I was going to buy another Replicator 2, but I will no longer support Makerbot.  I will buy a solidoodle, hell, I'll get 3 of them for the same price!  This greedy company is trying to monopolize the entire desktop 3d printing sector.  This impedes innovation, I hate corporations!!!!!!!!!!!  I think they were watching the industry, and planned this all along before they even bought makerbot.
comments.author: falken76

comments.text:
Wow...ok..go bury your head in the sand...that's worked for so many hipsters. <eye roll="">
Do you really think any of these half ass sites are going to challenge anyone but you uber-geek early adopters? Do you think the vast majority of users care? Take the 'clue hit' and look at the computer wars of the 80/90's, or the video game wars...or, hell, the cell phone wars.
The ONLY way to influence the discussion is to be in it, not pulling a Cartman and going away with your toys. That's exactly what they want you to do.Stay in the main sites...address the BS...ask questions...point out alternatives....but just leaving? Yeah...that'll teach them. Then all they have is a whole new generation of users who don't know any better.....they win.
I will also add that all of you who are outraged about this are just plain out of touch....this IS how real business is done. You guy's are all about open source....this ain't it and it's NEVER coming back...too much money to be made. Did you hear HP is getting into it? That means rednecks at Wallyworld will soon be online. They'll print 73,000 duck dynasty models and then they'll be suits about copyright infringement....everything is getting ready to be fast tracked. You can either jump on the train or take the hand car into the 1990's and stay there...
Cheers
comments.author: falken76

comments.text: Yes because no one is making money in the open source market like Linux and Arduino.  These communities have a culture that pushes them faster and further then there closed source counterparts and have a loyalty that other companies would kill for.  There is still tons of money to be made in open source and we can have a direct impact on where that money goes either an open source provider or a closed source.  When Stratasys comes and close up every other open or closed source solution we have most of our choices taken away.  I will not post new content to Thingiverse but that does not mean I am abandoning the conversation.  Sounds like your the one throwing the towel in assuming the battles have already been fought and the war has been won by the Monsanto of 3D printing.  It ain't over yet.

comments.text: This is the entire reason that my buddy and I built http://www.bld3r.comwww.bld3r.com!!! We wanted to provide an alternative to repositories owned by printer manufacturers, but we also wanted to give users the ability to find whatever file they wanted even if it is through a link to thingiverse. We are just two guys independent from any printer so there's no conflict of interest, but foremost we want to give creators full control over their files. We also wanted to make it as much like reddit and stackoverflow as possible. We just need your help (if you like us of course) getting cool files that people would like and that you'd like to share. We want what's best for the community. Please let us know how we can help.

comments.text: I completely agree with his object, we are at a real crossroads as a community.  If this type of behavior is successful, I cant think of any consumer level 3D printer that wouldn't be in violation of the patents they are defending.  The net they are throwing is so big and wide they would catch everyone.  It is  not attacking there infill pattern or logic being copied it attacking ANY infill of any kind and possibly the software as well.  Its not attacking a heated bed on a printer its attacking any way the build area could be heated.  I find it odd that   Stratasys hasn't defended any of these patents until they acquired  Makerbot.  This behavior in my opinion is in direct conflict of the open source nature of this community and the very roots that Makerbot where founded on.

comments.text: I too am in the process of copying my stuff to Youmagine. While I won't be removing my old items from here, that seems a little childish, I can't in good faith continue to support a site that is run buy a company seemingly hell bent on ruining what it seemed to have no interest in over the last 5 or so years. title: Workshop 88 mill limit switch mount to DRO

description.text:
Workshop 88 has a mini mill CNC conversion that needed limit switches. One of the easiest place to install them was on the DRO's attached to the machine. This thing is the clip designed to hold the limit switches to the DRO's. They are to be held in place with a 4-40 socket cap screw with a captured lock nut.

The clip along with models of the switch, nuts, socket cap screw, the DRO, and test pieces to print to find ideal hole diameters for your printer were all created in OpenSCAD and are included.

Workshop 88 is a maker space in Glen Ellyn, Illinois.
Check us out at http://workshop88.com

author: Jimbotron

description.text: A body-driven prosthetic hand, Raptor Reloaded, is remixed into a servo-driven hand capable of performing gestures. Controlled either by movements detected by an IMU or by an Android app via bluetooth.

Printer:

Fortus

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

35%

Notes:

Print count:
1: Palm
1: Wrist_plate
1: Servo_holder
1: Retention_clip
2: Wrist_pin
2: Wrist_cap
2: Knuckle_pin
4: Finger_pin
4: Finger_proximal
4: Finger_tip

Assembling Hand

Follow Raptor Reloaded assembly instructions here:

  • Instructables - Assembly-of-e-NABLEs-Raptor-Reloaded-Hand

I purchased my additional materials in a kit from here:

  • 3D Universe - Raptor Hand by e-NABLE - Assembly Materials Kit
Stringing the Hand General Breadboard Setup

Equipment Used

  • Microcontroller: Teensyduino 3.2
  • IMU - 6DoF: Sparkfun, LSM6DS3
  • Servos: SG90
  • Flex Sensor: Sparkfun
  • Battery Babysitter: Sparkfun
  • BLE Nano, V1.5 Redbear Labs
  • Battery - 800mAh 3.7V: Venom

Teensyduino Programming

The Teensyduino is made to be programmed via the Arduino IDE. I used version 1.6.11 - download it here:

  • https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software

Follow this tutorial to install the "Teensy Loader application" and the "Teensyduino installer"

  • https://www.pjrc.com/teensy/tutorial.html

Then you can upload code to the Teensyduino. My final code running on the Teensyduino is here Hand_Project.ino.

BLE Nano programming

To download firmware on the BLE Nano without the MK20 USB board, we must upload it OTA.
Follow the instructions here to install "RedBearLab nRF51822 Boards" add-on to the Arduino IDE:
https://github.com/RedBearLab/nRF51822-Arduino/#install-board-package-add-on

Download the nRF Connect app onto your Android phone:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=no.nordicsemi.android.mcp&hl=en

Arduino Code:

In Arduino, once you have the file you want to upload to the BLE Nano:

  1. Choose your board (Tools > Board > nRF51822(V1.5 32KB))
  2. Export your sketch as a .hex file: (Sketch > Export Compiled Binary)
  3. Upload the .hex file to Google Drive (or just email it to yourself)

Here is my .hex file: my_SimpleChat_OTA.hex
and the original Arduino sketch that I created it from: my_SimpleChat_new.ino

OTA Upload:

On your Android phone,

  1. Download the .hex file
  2. Open the nRF Connect app
  3. Power the BLE Nano, and scan until you see "DFU as a device - connect to it
    • the BLE Nano goes into bootloader mode for 5 seconds after resetting, this is when you can connect to it. Unplug and replug power to the chip to force into bootloader mode.
  4. Once connected, press the DFU button
  5. Choose "Application"
  6. Select your file from Downloads
  7. Select "no" for the init packet
    • It will now automatically try to upload the application, but the chip is no longer in bootloader mode (5 seconds have passed). Unplug and plug the chip quickly before it exits. If it connects in time, it will upload the application.
PCB Design Populated PCB

IMU Control

The hand has a 6 DoF IMU which is constantly reading accelerations in the x,y, and z directions as well as the angular velocity in those directions. Individual gestures are mapped to certain orientations of the hand (accelerometer data) as well as orientation and velocities. For example, multiple gestures can triggered when the hand is held upright with palm facing out. If the hand is moving forward and backwards quickly, it triggers the "rock on" gesture. If the hand is rotating about the axis of the arm, the "hang loose" gesture is triggered.

The

Android Application

My app was based off of one of Redbear Lab's example apps .

  • Original app: Chat
  • My app: Chat

The app searches for and connects to the BLE Nano, and then allows the user to begin sending gesture commands to the hand. The hand automatically begins in the IMU-controlled state, so the user must first press the "start" button and the hand will switch to the app-controlled state. They can now press any gesture button, which sends an integer to the BLE Nano which gets sent through to the Teensyduino. The Teensyduino is set up to echo whatever it receives, so on the bottom of the app screen we can see the numbers we have just sent (mainly for debugging purposes).

What I would do differently

  • CAD Design:

    • The two middle servos are just a little too close to not hit each other, when they sweep around. Currently I have the right servo sitting about half a cm higher than the other so it sweeps above the other.
  • PCB Design:
    • In my servo connections, I have the ground and power pins opposite to how they are ordered physically. I had to cut and re-solder the servo wires.
    • The battery connection and the flex sensor connection on the PCB both stick out on the side which sits up against the servo holder. This makes wiring a little awkward, and the pcb cannot sit flush with the servo holder.

print_settings.Notes:: Example show was printed on the printer described above in Hatchbox PLA with Repetier/Slic3r software.
print_settings.Printer:: XYZ Da Vinci 1.0A Hacked with E3D V6 and Repetier V92

description.text:
Use to determine which features will print sufficiently to be a functional part of a mechanical print.

A Minimum Viable Feature is more than just what will make it through your slicer and onto the bed of your machine, although that is interesting.

Minimum Viable Features are the smallest things that are actually useful. Solid modeling is deceptive at times - it's easy to lose track of the scale and size you're working at. Run this test part, decide the threshold of usefulness by size or angle of each of the different features. Then bake those into your design process as the minimums that you'll use.

Part includes:
Slot, wall and cylindrical pin in sizes from 0.1 to 2.0mm in 0.1mm steps
Overhangs from 70deg to 25deg from horizontal, in 5 degree increments.

Hope you find it useful. If you use it, please post a pic with some details on your print - printer model, material and manufacturer, slicer used, etc.

Thanks.

comments.text: What nozzle size did you use on your print?
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text: I used 0.4 nozzle with 0.3mm layers, default extrusion width on Repetier/Slic3r.
comments.author: OderWat

comments.text: Did you measure the results? How can a 0,4 mm nozzle print the 0.1 up to 0.4 mm wide structures and why does the slicer even try to do this in the gcode?
comments.author: MatthewGTaylor

comments.text: It's a really good point - the test is a good indication of the slicer algorithms at the small end of the feature size. Slic3r will provide Gcode for the walls from .3mm wide and above, but it can only step in even extrusion widths at the smaller sizes. So for everything up to .5 it lays one trace at about .45 wide (using a .3mm layer height and auto-generated extrusion widths). I have since set my extrusion width to .5mm for a predictable result and try to design my wall thicknesses in .5mm increments at the low end.
comments.author: OderWat

title: 80mm cooling fan for  Mk8 dual extruder by Geeetech/ LEDs

description.text: This is an 80mm fan mount for the pre assembled Mk8 dual extruder by Geeetech. I would like to thank "bmxorcist" he was the one that inspired me to do this mod to my Hictop Aluminum Frame printer. I used his his firmware update and his "Prusa i3 Dual Mk8 X Carriage" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1347192). I was not happy with not having any fan devoted to cooling the extruder, so after trying some other designs with multiple fans I came up with this. This design uses one 80mm fan to cool the extruders and the hot ends. I works well, a little to well. WARNING do not run the fan on full speed it will warp the print BAD. I don't run the fan at all for the first few layers and only run it at around 50% the rest of the time. My extruders stay cool and I used the two 40mm fans that came off the old design to cool my y and x axis motors. I also added LEDs because why not. Visibility to my hot end is better then I thought it would be. You can look directly through the fan and see both extruders great.

description.text:
This is my personal design of a RC car in 1:26 scale (approximately). All things are designed and printed by me in solid translucent blue PLA on my Ultimaker. Only 0.5 module 49 tooth gear was printed in yellow PLA. For the car electronics I used an Arduino Mini compatible board, a Pololu DRV8835 motor driver and a rf24 2Euros RC module. The steering is commanded with a Hitec HS-55 feather servo.
The controller is made with a PS2 dualshock controller, another Arduino (Nano) and another rf24 module. I have not printed the body car yet because the electronic is "fat"... Great RC car, my ultra hard tire give the ability to do great drift! Here there is a video of the controller: http://youtu.be/aQmGHKu2lxE and making some drift: http://youtu.be/qicIYKGRASU I hope you enjoy. I am here for every question Bye. GCopper 20131201: Added sketches
20131202: Added mechanical BOM and step assembly

description.text:
My office at work has an electric stapler that like any stapler, periodically jams. In order to clear it, an included clockwork key is used to manually advance the mechanism. However, the key went missing and the manufacturer (Swingline) does not offer replacement parts. (A new stapler would cost ~$USD 200.)

Thus, I reverse-engineered a different key for the same model to create a replacement.

This was created for the model 520e stapler, but should also work in its replacement, the 50201 and 50204. As this is an entirely functional part, it's not patentable and hereby released into the public domain.
